body: Two young women, lifelong friends who vanished early Friday after leaving a nightclub in Jamaica, Queens, were found yesterday morning locked inside a storefront about half a mile away. One had been badly beaten and the other had apparently been bludgeoned to death. The discovery was made by the members of a social club who recognized the women's
title: Woman Found Slain in Store in Queens

body: NEW YORK 3 Charged in Officer's Death Three men were charged with murder in the shooting deaths of an off-duty police officer and a Queens merchant last week. The arrests, which came after one of the suspects was picked up on a minor drug charge, were hailed by Police Commissioner Howard Safir as an especially gratifying example of how the city's
title: Metro Digest

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's increasingly confident appraisal of his re-election prospects has not come as a surprise to the Democratic leaders who would like to unseat him. Many of them have been saying the same thing -- if less publicly -- for months. ''Sober Democrats appreciate that Giuliani is currently the favorite,'' said Mark J. Green, the
title: Can He Be Beaten?

body: IN khaki pants, denim shirt and longish gray-white bangs, N. Jay Jaffee may bear a passing resemblance to the abstract painter Willem de Kooning. But at 75, Mr. Jaffee is celebrating a half-century in photography, not painting. His best-known images, of New York street scenes of the 1940's and 50's, have been exhibited alongside the documentary
title: After 50 Years, Looking for Fresh Images

body: From midtown Manhattan to Riverdale to the Rockaways, New York City's crime rate has plunged for the third straight year, dropping 16 percent below last year's figures, preliminary Police Department records show. New York City is on a pace to have fewer than 1,000 murders in a year, which would be the lowest total since 1968; 937 were reported by
title: New York Crime Rate Plummets To Levels Not Seen in 30 Years

body: For most New Yorkers, the memory and emotional impact of what happened in Howard Beach, Queens, 10 years ago this Friday have faded. But for Jean Griffith Sandiford, the racial killing remains as vivid and piercing as ever, the wound still throbbing. ''When I got the call, how I screamed,'' Mrs. Sandiford, a 53-year-old woman with a soft voice,
title: Mother Still Mourns Racial-Killing Victim

body: The stark facts of Cecilia Gibson's life frustrate her. She is 37, healthy and able to work. But she does not have a job. She has five children, two with infants of their own, and she cares for all seven alone. The father of three of her children is in jail, she said. The father of another has disappeared and pays no child support. Ms. Gibson has
title: Mother Confronts Her Mistakes and Her Family's

body: ''I saw a woman killed here, run over by a van,'' Alva Gonzalez said, pointing at a crosswalk at Parsons Boulevard and Jamaica Avenue in Jamaica, Queens. Moments earlier, she had needed a little quick footwork to escape the same fate. City officials have designated the intersection one of the 20 most dangerous in New York for pedestrians, but Ms.
title: Where New York Pedestrians Risk Life and Limb Every Day

body: The Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday that he would seek the death penalty in a second case, this one against a 22-year-old man accused of killing another man execution style while stealing a jeweled gold pendant and necklace from him. District Attorney Charles J. Hynes, who has said he opposes the death penalty, is still the only New York
title: Brooklyn Prosecutor Seeks Death Penalty in a 2d Case

body: In September and November of 1995, two old acquaintances met in a Brooklyn apartment. Charles Johnson proposed to rob a drug dealer's home. He asked Charles Price for help. But that was not Mr. Johnson's real agenda, court papers say. Instead, the papers say, he was trying to get Mr. Price to admit involvement in one of the city's most notorious
title: Prosecutors Say Videotaped Meetings Back Their Evidence That Suspect Incited Crowd

body: In the two months since the Rev. Al Sharpton stood at a Harlem pulpit and announced his intention to run for mayor, many in New York City's political firmament have speculated on whether the Baptist minister was truly serious about becoming the city's 108th mayor. But in the last few weeks, Mr. Sharpton has taken a series of steps that, he
title: Sharpton's Political Move: A Brooklyn House

body: Three people who were still in jail more than a week after the police found a cache of weapons in the Brooklyn headquarters of a group described as a leftist cult were released yesterday on sharply reduced bail. The release of the three women, on $1,000 bail each, came after they had been held on $100,000 each since Nov. 13, two days after the
title: 3 Released After Bail Is Reduced To $1,000

body: Despite a continuing citywide drop in crime, several neighborhoods in southern Queens, northern Brooklyn and the Bronx have experienced an unusual upsurge in murders and shootings this month, according to a police report. The internal document reported that there were 53 murders in the city between Nov. 1 and Nov. 17, compared with 40 murders
title: Police Report More Violence In Some Areas

body: A hospital workers' union went to court this week to collect almost $14 million owed its pension and benefits fund by the Interfaith Medical Center of Brooklyn, prompting the hospital to lay off 330 employees. The debt and the layoffs, affecting about 15 percent of the work force, reflect the continuing financial troubles of an old, private
title: Union Sues a Medical Center For Millions in Pension Funds

body: Nearly three years after he left office, former Mayor David N. Dinkins was sharply questioned once again yesterday about his handling of the 1991 Crown Heights racial violence, as part of a lawsuit by Hasidic Jews who contend that Mr. Dinkins initially withheld police protection from Hasidic victims. It was the second time in the four-year-old
title: Dinkins Under Lights Again on Crown Heights

body: Even as a young man -- before he formally declared war on northern California -- Gerald William Doeden was known as a fast-talking con artist who got away with cashing checks in bars signed ''Jesus H. Christ'' and could quote Shakespeare from memory by the yard. Jeri Doeden went on to become Field Commander Eugenio Perente-Ramos, an entirely
title: Its Leader Dead, a Fringe Group Lives On

body: A week after the police raided the headquarters of a heavily armed fringe group in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, some group members were back yesterday, busily bagging leaves, sweeping, painting -- and making some of their tenants and neighbors exceedingly nervous. A few tenants, still unnerved by the raid, made an impromptu bid for professional help.
title: Tenants Are Anxious as Group Returns

body: TROUBLE not of their making has made partners of Carlton Collier and Martin Horwitz, one from the nonprofit world, the other a private owner. They are working together on a rehabilitation project in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn that illustrates the new ties forming between the nonprofit and for-profit sectors as public subsidies for
title: The Growing Nonprofit Partnership With For-Profits

body: Tensions flared yesterday between a secretive underground organization in Brooklyn and the tenants who live alongside them as members of the group began returning home after being arrested during a raid in which a stockpile of illegal weapons was found. Several tenants of the cluster of Crown Heights buildings where the group maintained its
title: Tenants Wary as Members Of Raided Group Go Home

body: NEW YORK Fringe Group Enlisted Students While the stated aim of the National Labor Federation was to mobilize workers to challenge the fundamental economic system, it appears to have achieved little in that arena. What has perhaps drawn the greatest attention to the group is its recruiting efforts among a very different group: idealistic college
title: METRO DIGEST

body: As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani displayed what he called ''an enormous cache of weapons that can be used for mass destruction,'' officials said yesterday that a grand jury would investigate the secretive group that amassed the stockpile of guns and ammunition in a cluster of Brooklyn apartment buildings. The Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J.
title: Grand Jury Seeks Reason Behind a Group's Arsenal

body: NEW YORK Complaint Led to Arms Cache A routine complaint of a child's cries led the police to stumble on the headquarters of what they called a heavily armed leftist cult that had been living quietly in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn for some 20 years. Police officials said that the 30 people arrested in the late-night raid were followers of
title: METRO DIGEST

body: A routine complaint about a crying child Monday night led the police to stumble onto the headquarters of what they called a heavily armed leftist cult that had been living quietly in Brooklyn for 20 years, talking into the night of impending revolution and filling out mounds of bureaucratic paperwork. Police officials said yesterday that the 30
title: Drawn by Child's Cries, Police Uncover Arsenal

body: The people arrested in Monday night's raid on a Brooklyn building were followers, the police say, of a labor organizer turned cult leader who died last year, a man whose past is clouded by aliases, murky organizations and questionable claims. Gerald William Doeden, known for much of his life as Eugenio Perente-Ramos, was the founder and leader of
title: Group's Leader Is Said to Have Used Cult Tactics

body: For Robert Dieterich, life as a Nynex customer finally became intolerable last spring, when he started getting calls for Randi Baker, his next-door neighbor in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. After some detective work, Mr. Dieterich discovered that Ms. Baker had asked the phone company to fix her line because it was scratchy. A Nynex repair man
title: New Rivals and Pending Merger Force a Company to Focus on Service

body: Having announced that they will consider reopening the case of the Bronx police officer who was acquitted this week of the choking death of an asthmatic, Federal prosecutors will probably turn to the same civil rights statute that was used to convict two Los Angeles police officers for the beating of Rodney King. But the King case, in 1993, was
title: Rights Trial for Livoti May Be Tricky

body: GREENWICH VILLAGE Lecture Spotlight Turns To Drummer for Ellington Rocky White, the drummer, will be the subject on Tuesday night as Arnold Jay Smith continues his lecture series at the New School on the jazz legacies of Duke Ellington and his son, Mercer. Mr. White joined the band toward the end of Duke Ellington's career and was the only drummer
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: In another indication of the magnitude of overcrowding in New York City's public schools, the teachers' union reported yesterday that one of every six classes had more students than allowed under the union's contract with the city. In many classes the number of students registered is only one or two above the limit, which is 32 in elementary
title: Teachers Step Up Pressure On Issue of Overcrowding

body: HUNDREDS of shoes -- from scruffy sneakers to spit-shined wingtips -- were piled high on Barbara Hohlt's dining room table on Sunday. Nearby, a dozen people busily rooted through bags and boxes of even more shoes, making her Brooklyn Heights home look like the epicenter of a specialty tag sale. Some shoes' laces were tied to small notes. A note
title: Victims' Shoes Are a Protest Of Gun Deaths

body: As the Rev. Al Sharpton formally announced his candidacy for Mayor yesterday, Democratic leaders said that his surprise entry into the race would complicate their efforts to regain City Hall next year. Mr. Sharpton announced his candidacy to a packed congregation during the morning service at Canaan Baptist Church in Harlem, issuing a blistering
title: Sharpton's Candidacy Has Democratic Leaders Stewing Over Strategy

body: ''There's a little proverb,'' Barbara Byrd-Bennett rattled off in her signature rapid-fire staccato. ''Go to the people, learn from them, serve them, plan with them. Start with what they know and build on what they have. When the current leaders leave, the people will say, 'We have done it ourselves.' '' It is a parable, she said, that has guided
title: After Reviving District, a Citywide Challenge

body: The Rev. Al Sharpton, who twice sought a seat in the United States Senate, will announce today that he will run in next year's Democratic primary for mayor, his office said yesterday. Mr. Sharpton plans to make his announcement in Harlem during a sermon at the Canaan Baptist Church, where he conducts weekly rallies. The announcement, which seemed
title: Sharpton Announcing Run for Mayor, as Democrat

body: Days after last week's New York Democratic primary, Clarence Norman Jr. could barely hide his exhilaration. Sipping a soda and smiling broadly while discussing a race for a little-known judicial position, he made it clear that he had been buoyed by the results of his handiwork in a campaign that he hoped would define his stewardship as the leader
title: Party Leader Tests Gears in Brooklyn Machine

body: The new Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, paid back a crucial political debt in New York City yesterday when he visited the grave of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the Lubavitch leader whose followers in Israel worked diligently toward Mr. Netanyahu's narrow victory in late May. In a brisk 27-hour visit to New York -- part of his
title: Israeli Prime Minister Pays Visit, and a Political Debt

body: In a bustling storefront headquarters in Crown Heights, Clarence A. Norman spent most of yesterday commanding troops of campaign volunteers, discussing last-minute strategies on leafleting and getting voters to polls. While Mr. Norman, a State Assemblyman, faces his own race in tomorrow's Democratic primary, his more pressing focus was on the
title: Primary Races Are Obscure, but Reputations Are on the Line

body: ON a humid morning last week, Michael D. Benjamin stood at the entrance to the subway station at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, passing out campaign material and urging riders to vote for his candidate. Some people stopped and listened. Many simply darted by, looking more than a little annoyed. After all, Mr. Benjamin was stumping for a candidate in
title: Wake Up! It's Primary Time

author: Sara Mosle is a contributing writer for the Magazine.
body: TO HIS STUDENTS, Michael A. Johnson is a little like one of those slightly overbearing parents -- the kind who is always packing off his kids to private schools and tutors or Stanley Kaplan courses to make sure that they get into an Ivy League college. The principal and founder of the Science Skills Center, a three-year-old public high school at
title: SCORES COUNT

body: A brand new school might be expected to bring a smile to the faces of parents in central Brooklyn. Instead, many of those who brought their children to Public School 22, at St Mark's Place and Classon Avenue, in Crown Heights, on Thursday and Friday had little but complaints -- about unfinished construction work, buses that arrived late or not at
title: New School Ushers In Old Complaints

body: New York City sends more than 60 legislators to the State Assembly, but most do not face difficult races this November, and only a few will be opposed in next Tuesday's primaries. Here are the more serious contests. 36th District (Queens): Democratic primary. Denis Butler, 69, has represented this Astoria-based district for 20 years. Although we
title: The Assembly Primaries

body: NEW YORK Agency Had Evidence of Abuse The Commissioner of the city's Administration for Children's Services acknowledged that evidence of neglect was found 15 months ago at the home of Nadine Lockwood, the 4-year-old whose mother is accused of starving her to death. But he said that after an initial review of records he could not explain what
title: Metro Digest

body: The prosecutor leading the investigation into the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic scholar during racial violence in Crown Heights in 1991 says the possibility is becoming ''more and more remote'' that additional people will be charged in the killing besides the two men indicted so far. While prominent politicians and members of the victim's family
title: Prosecutors Are Stalled In '91 Clash

body: Labor Day is Monday. This year's Labor Day Parade in Manhattan, however, begins at noon on Sept. 7, proceeding up Fifth Avenue from 44th to 86th Street. Here is a sampling of activities scheduled for this weekend in the metropolitan region. New York City Today ''DANCING UNDER THE STARS,'' Francis Lewis Park, Third Avenue and 147th Street,
title: Celebrating the Last Gasp of Summer, From the Arts to the Zoo

body: The lawyer for the man charged with instigating the fatal attack on a Hasidic doctoral student in the 1991 Crown Heights violence plans to argue that even if his client did all the things the prosecution has said, he did not commit the civil rights crime he is charged with. As a result, the lawyer said he would seek dismissal of the indictment on
title: Lawyer Disputes Validity of Charge in Crown Hts. Case

body: Shouting ''Let's go get a Jew'' and ''I'm going to get a Jew; who's with me?'' Charles Price whipped a group of blacks in Crown Heights into a murderous frenzy five years ago, a prosecutor charged yesterday, also suggesting for the first time in court that Mr. Price directed the mob to kill a Hasidic scholar. Speaking at a bail hearing, the
title: Official Says Man Told Mob To 'Get a Jew'

body: Five years after a Hasidic Jew was fatally stabbed during racial violence in Crown Heights, the streets of the Brooklyn neighborhood are no doubt quieter. But the killing continues to reverberate through the city, and yesterday -- the anniversary of the attack -- some of New York's top political leaders returned to the scene, saying that justice
title: Five Years and Two Suspects Later, a Call for Justice in Crown Heights

body: NEW YORK Many Drawn to Harlem Program One of New York City's largest and most eagerly awaited economic development programs in decades, the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, has received a torrent of applications from entrepreneurs, officials said. Under the program, more than $250 million in city, state and Federal funds are to be distributed to
title: METRO DIGEST

body: One car of a subway train derailed along the Franklin Avenue shuttle line in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon after it struck a piece of concrete that appeared to have been deliberately placed on the tracks, transit officials said. There were no injuries, though it was unclear how many passengers were on board the shuttle train when it derailed at
title: Franklin Avenue Shuttle Derails

body: At a celebration of Jamaican independence in Prospect Park the other day, the seating arrangement offered a snapshot of the political heavyweights of Caribbean Brooklyn. City Councilwoman Una Clarke, who organized the event, sat at a center table up front, with the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden. Later, she was joined by Mr. Golden's
title: A Snapshot Of Influence Of Caribbean

body: RABBI ISRAEL SHEMTOV seems to pop up in the right place at the right time. Three years ago in his Crown Heights neighborhood, he rescued a woman who, bleeding profusely from nearly a dozen bullet wounds, was crawling out of a basement. He hauled her into his car and sped to a nearby hospital. On Monday, three years to the day, he was driving over
title: For a Rabbi, Doing Good Is Doing Well

body: NEW YORK Adults in Shelters Must Work In a significant expansion of the city's workfare program, homeless adults living with their families in city shelters will now be required to work for the city in exchange for their welfare benefits, aides to Mayor Giuliani said. The plan will take effect this fall for most of the 5,700 adults with children
title: Metro Digest

body: When law enforcement officials announced the arrest of the man they called ''the key person'' in inciting racial unrest in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in 1991, they described the suspect as a sturdily built bald black man who had been identified from television video footage. But the year was 1992, not 1996. And the man in custody was Raymond Wesley,
title: Same Charge, New Suspect, Five Years After Murder

body: THERE is a timelessness about Crown Heights, a weary grittiness broken only by a flash of humor or an attempt at optimism from people who live apart even as they live together. It was that way five years ago, when the Brooklyn neighborhood erupted in violence, and 17 years ago, during another period of unrest. And it was that way -- still --
title: In Crown Hts., Elusive Quest For Justice

body: THE CONVENTION Pataki as Nominator Two Bob Dole, as expected, was named the Republican Party's candidate for the Presidency last night. Less expectedly, Governor Pataki, who had said he would not speak at the convention, gave the nominating speech for the Vice Presidential candidate, Jack Kemp. $(Page A1.$) NEW YORK Arrest in Crown Hts. Violence
title: Metro Digest

body: Nearly five years after the violent racial clashes that tore through Crown Heights in Brooklyn, Federal law enforcement officials said yesterday that they had arrested a 43-year-old man whom they described as a prime instigator in the unrest that led to the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic scholar. In an indictment unsealed yesterday, Federal officials
title: MAN HELD IN ROLE IN CROWN HTS. CASE

body: On a warm summer night five years ago, a 7-year-old black boy stopped to adjust the chain on his bicycle near an intersection in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. The boy, Gavin Cato, was the first person to be in the wrong place at the wrong time in a series of events that destroyed two lives, blighted many others and did lasting damage to
title: The Case That Rocked Crown Heights

body: International A3-16 SUSPECTS IN SAUDI BOMBING The Government of Saudi Arabia now believes that native Saudi Islamic militants carried out the June 25 bombing that killed 19 American servicemen. A1 A NEW PALESTINIAN SYMBOL An international airport being built in the Gaza Strip is testing the limits of Palestinian autonomy. A3 QUESTIONABLE TRUCE IN
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: In using a Federal civil rights statute to charge a second Brooklyn man with the 1991 death of a Hasidic student, prosecutors may have a tough time. They must persuade a jury that a man who utters anti-Semitic invective can be held as responsible for a homicide as the man who does the stabbing. Both Charles Price, 43, and the original defendant,
title: Proving Incitement Is Complicated Task

body: In a series of unrelated incidents across the city, six women and girls reported that they were the victims of sex attacks over the weekend, the police said yesterday. The six attacks followed a week in which there were several particularly troubling sex crimes in the city, including the rape of a 17-year-old girl, in which a police officer has
title: Six Sex Attacks Reported Over Weekend

body: Greg Plate and his cousin, Danny Noonan, boarded the ferry looking for their hero Joe DiMaggio and hoping he would sign three baseballs. Kathleen McCarthy was looking only for a cold beer. While neither succeeded, both acknowledged that the trip aboard the Yankee Clipper was thoroughly enjoyable. Yesterday was the first run for the ferry service,
title: Maiden Voyage of the Yankee Clipper

body: Newsweek yesterday found itself explaining how it was that a performance artist, Anna Deavere Smith, wound up representing the news weekly on Air Force One. Ms. Smith had been given Newsweek credentials to cover the two major political parties' conventions as a guest writer for the magazine, writing one, primarily impressionistic, piece about each
title: POLITICS: THE MEDIA;Artist as Pool Reporter: The Reviews Are Mixed

body: In courtrooms and classrooms across New York City, several dozen judges have been convening to consider not robberies or murders or petty crimes, but how to fight bigotry. The judges, who call themselves Blacks and Jews in Conversation, preside over everything from Housing Court to the Court of Appeals, but they put aside their robes at least once
title: Off the Bench and Into Classrooms, Judges Unite to Fight Bias

body: The day before T.W.A. Flight 800 exploded in flames and plunged into the Atlantic, a traveler stopped into Our Lady of the Skies Chapel at Kennedy International Airport and penciled a plea to God in the visitors' book: "Let everyone be safe." Three days later, Julie Maher sat on a wooden pew in the same chapel -- a carpeted room with oak-paneled
title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE CHAPLAINS;Kennedy Airport Provides a Sanctuary for Catholics, Protestants and Jews

body: The Sidewalk Patrol Q. Last week, I saw a group of earnest young men and women with clipboards and sketchbooks hovering at Broadway just below Eighth Street. Thinking they were artists, I asked them what they were up to, and they responded without looking up: "Counting." Counting what, I continued. "People." Aha. My question: Is the city actually
title: F.Y.I.

body: 'Shakespeare in Brooklyn II' Brooklyn Children's Museum 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Marks Avenue Crown Heights (718) 735-4402 Recommended ages: 5 and up Sunday If it's July, it must mean Shakespeare in Brooklyn. In this second annual event, the playwright and the 16th century become slightly more meaningful and relevant in an outdoor rooftop
title: For Children

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Daphney Nerette lay down to sleep Friday night, her infant daughter at her side and her fiance, Marcus Calcador, reading religious literature in another room. Suddenly, she said, Mr. Calcador burst in, waving a pair of scissors and saying, "One of you is evil and one of you all has to go." What followed was a rampage that ended when Mr. Calcador
title: Infant Falls To Her Death In the Arms Of Her Father

body: The parents of a 13-year-old student who drowned on an overnight trip to Philadelphia announced a $75 million wrongful death suit against the Board of Education and the city yesterday, a day after a second youth died of injuries received in the same incident. Jason Moore, 14, died on Tuesday after being on life support at the Children's Hospital of
title: Parents of Drowned Student Sue the Board of Education

body: Acting partly in response to fierce criticism surrounding a Manhattan jury's acquittal of a man charged with setting a fire that killed a firefighter in 1994, Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they were looking into filing Federal arson charges against the man. The United States Attorney, Mary Jo White, said prosecutors had begun to "explore"
title: Federal Charges Weighed In Fireman's Death in Blaze

body: A 14-year-old boy who spent 10 days on a life support system after he was rescued from a Philadelphia swimming pool during a school trip died yesterday, a hospital spokeswoman said. Jason Moore, who had been in critical condition at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia since June 22, died at 7 P.M., said the spokeswoman, Brenda Hicks. She would
title: Boy in Coma After Rescue From Pool Is Dead at 14

body: Screams and sobs echoed through the vaulted nave of St. Francis of Assisi Church in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn yesterday as hundreds of mourners gathered for the funeral of Marc C. Britou Jr., a 13-year-old honors student who drowned last weekend while on a school trip. But anger kept bursting through the palpable grief. Relatives,
title: Student Who Drowned on Trip Is Mourned With Tears and Anger at aBrooklyn Funeral

body: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy who drowned in a hotel pool in Philadelphia while on a school trip was left in the pool even as a classmate was being rescued, apparently because the water was so murky that rescuers could not see the bottom, a Philadelphia police detective said yesterday. The detective said it was not until Jason Moore, 14, was pulled
title: Murky Pool Hindered Rescue Of Brooklyn Boy, Police Say

body: A 13-year-old Brooklyn student on a science field trip drowned in a Philadelphia motel pool Saturday evening, leaving many questions and conflicting reports, even two days later, about whether he and other students had been properly supervised by the adults who accompanied them. Mark Britou, an honors student at Intermediate School 61 in Crown
title: Trying to Save Friend, Teen-Ager on Field Trip Drowns in Motel Pool

title: Advertisements for Himself

body: The basketball sailed over the high stone wall along St. Johns Place in Brooklyn, just missing the statue of Mary and the baby Jesus that rises forlornly above a block of graffiti-scarred row houses. The ball's 13-year-old owner walked cautiously to the black iron gates of the Monastery of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, pressed a button and retreated to
title: Medieval Fortress of Spirituality;Cloaked in Mystery, Brooklyn Nuns Do Their Work: Prayer

body: SISTER MARY MORROW not only works in a hospital. She once also lived in one. The nun, whom patients and staff at the Mercy Medical Center refer to as Sister Mary Sunshine because of her bright disposition, spent much of her childhood in the dark confines of a polio ward. At 4 she was given a diagnosis of polio. "It was the 1930's," she recalled.
title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND;Been There, Done That, but Ever an Optimist

body: International 3-12 IRAQ'S STOLEN ANTIQUITIES As Iraqis continue to suffer from stringent economic sanctions, art experts and archeologists say, precious antiquities from ancient civilizations are pouring into the international market to raise cash. 1 A NEW COURSE FOR INDIA With the new Prime Minister, India has marked a transition from a leadership
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: IN their own modest ways, Barbara Thompson, a tenant, and Denis Gittens, a landlord, are at the center of an already brewing storm over whether a half-century of rent regulation in New York State will end -- or be significantly altered -- precisely one year from today. Each fits the billboard image that contending sides in the debate choose to
title: As Battle Looms On Rent Law, Skirmishing Has Begun

body: Rabbi Mechel Handler cannot forget the emergency call he got from a man who, between gasping and choking, spoke the word "booth." Certain that the man was on Booth Street in Flushing, Queens, Rabbi Handler sent out an ambulance and called the phone company to trace the call. Fifteen minutes later, torn between interrupting the trace and opening the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CROWN HEIGHTS;Lots of Data in a Call for Help

body: Gov. George E. Pataki unveiled a plan today that would help connect every public school and library in the state to the Internet, putting out a call for volunteers to conduct a mass wiring of buildings across the state on a single day in September. Mr. Pataki said New York must ready its children for the next century by giving them the opportunity
title: Pataki Calls for Internet Wiring Day at Schools

body: It was September 1991, the summer of the violence in Crown Heights. Tensions between blacks and Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn erupted after a Hasidic driver struck and killed a 7-year-old black child. In retaliation, black youths attacked and killed a Hasidic Jew. Three weeks later, in Far Rockaway, Queens, another incident sounded disturbing echoes. A
title: Keeping Peace Alive And Tensions Dormant;Diverse Far Rockaway Sees Room For Harmony as Jewish Enclave Grows

body: NEW YORK For Some Parents, Lawyers Fail For the parents, almost all of them poor, whose children have been removed from their households by child-welfare authorities, the legal system can be daunting. Their court-appointed lawyers are overburdened and ill equipped, according to parents, lawyers and judges. With the merits of the city's case
title: METRO DIGEST

body: Will listening to a make-believe talking tree bring city children closer to the real trees on their streets? Will playing with mud and sticks get them closer to the earth? The Brooklyn Children's Museum thinks so. The museum, which was closed for nine months for a $7 million renovation, reopened its doors in Crown Heights on May 18 with a new
title: Introducing Youngsters To the Joys Of Greenery

body: IN the newly renovated Brooklyn Children's Museum, which reopened earlier this month, there are a new workshop, greenhouse, galleries, a computer-access system, gift shop and a rooftop performance and play area. There is even a precursor of the Swatch -- a sundial where a child's shadow falls on the correct time (above right). The total cost was $7
title: Currents;Lively Learning at the Renovated Brooklyn Children's Museum

body: Less than two weeks after members of a Hasidic patrol group were arrested in the beating of a black man in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Police Commissioner Howard Safir met with representatives of patrols from throughout the city yesterday and emphasized that they were not to become involved in physical confrontations. Commissioner Safir and other
title: Safir Warns Civilian Patrols On Avoiding Confrontations

body: A day after a confrontation left five people injured in the Stapleton housing project on Staten Island, police officials and residents offered sharply different accounts of the scuffle yesterday. Residents said the officers used excessive force, while police officials accused several people of inciting the violence. Chief of Department Louis R.
title: Blame for Violence Is Disputed on S.I.

body: DEVELOPERS using public and private funds under New York City's new Neighborhood Entrepreneur Program are rehabilitating nearly 1,200 rental apartments for low- and moderate-income families. The apartments, in neighborhoods including Harlem and Bedford-Stuyvesant and Crown Heights in Brooklyn, are to be restored by the middle of next year. Most
title: Real Estate;A new program is rehabilitating some 1,200 rental apartments in New York City.

body: Three men were critically wounded yesterday in an afternoon shooting at an apartment building in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the police said. Doram Tamari, a spokesman for the Police Department, said the shooting occurred shortly before 4 P.M. at 992 Eastern Parkway, on the third floor of a neatly kept four-story apartment building. Two of the victims
title: 3 Men Wounded in Shootings At Crown Heights Apartments

body: Fed up with television cameras and mortified by their neighborhood's resurgent image as a roiling racial caldron, Jewish and black residents of Crown Heights yesterday expressed both a conviction that they live in harmony and a determination to put a disruption on Thursday night behind them. But some things are easier said than done. Not far
title: Incidents in Crown Heights Draw New Calls for Harmony

body: NEW YORK Lessons Unlearned Outrageous tales of corruption emerge periodically from New York City's local school districts -- cash bribes paid for principalships, a cabal of top-level educators accused of conspiring to steal a school board election. Now, a close look at several districts around the city shows clearly the debilitating toll that
title: Metro Digest

In this project, three years in the planning, activities at the garden
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: The Rev. Al Sharpton praised the Police Department yesterday for arresting two members of a Hasidic civilian patrol who are accused of beating a black man with a radio in Crown Heights, but Mr. Sharpton questioned the suspects' speedy release from custody by saying it had raised troubling questions of preferential treatment. The confrontation,
title: Sharpton Hails Police in Arrest Of Two Hasidic Patrol Members

body: Members of a Hasidic patrol group who fought with a black man in Crown Heights on Thursday night violated police rules intended to prevent vigilantism when they chased down a crime suspect instead of simply calling the police, police officials said yesterday. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the group's leaders would be called in by the Police
title: Hasidic Patrol Group Faces Questions After a Crown Heights Clash

body: NEW YORK Buying Taxi Medallions Fifty-three cab drivers, nearly all of them born half a world away, became entrepreneurs as the winning bidders in New York City's first sale of new taxi medallions since the Depression. Even skeptics conceded that the Taxi and Limousine Commission's sale of 53 medallions for owner-drivers, and another 80 for taxi
title: Metro Digest

body: Two members of a Hasidic neighborhood patrol group in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, who were searching for a stolen bicycle were arrested on assault charges yesterday after they beat a black man with their walkie-talkies, the police said. The incident occurred at 8:15 P.M. outside the victim's home on Empire Boulevard, Officer Debra Kearns, a police
title: 2 From Hasidic Patrol Group Are Arrested in Attack on Man

body: It was school board election day in New York City yesterday, and Carmelo Saez Jr., ousted as president of his board by three successive chancellors on charges of corruption and patronage, was making the rounds of polling places in the West Bronx. At one, he angrily told poll workers to be sure not to lose the votes cast by himself, his relatives
title: Election Day for School Boards Mixes Apathy, Anger and Disgust

body: WE came looking for a better way of life," said Philip Leblang, explaining what brought him and his family to the Amalgamated Warbasse Houses middle-income co-op in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn 32 years ago, when it was newly built. title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

title: School Disparities Cited in Gifted Programs

title: A Little Brooklyn Job With Lots of Influence

body: Two big telephone cables were knocked out in Brooklyn yesterday, disrupting communications among a half-dozen police precincts and making the world a lot smaller for thousands of borough residents for much of the afternoon and evening. Nynex spokesmen said the problem started about 12:30 P.M. in a manhole at Linden Boulevard and East 98th Street in
title: Brooklyn Cable Fire Cuts Phone Service

body: Defying the conventional wisdom that drug dealing is an ineradicable plague, the New York City Police Department next week will put up to 3,000 officers and weapons ranging from new computer software to hydraulic battering rams into its biggest assault ever on neighborhood pushers. While skeptical criminologists cite a history of failed antidrug
title: Police to Start Big Offensive Against Drugs

body: Officer Anthony Falconite gazed at the line of battered livery cabs idling in the rain. It looked like robbery weather. "These guys are immigrants who work 16 hours a day," he said. "I feel terrible that somebody could take their day's work -- and maybe their life -- in one shot." He and other members of the Police Department's street crime unit
title: Cab Crimes Drop, but Drivers' Fears Remain High

body: Lemrick Nelson Jr., the man facing civil rights charges in the fatal attack on a Hasidic scholar during the Crown Heights racial violence in 1991, was acquitted yesterday on charges that he assaulted a police officer last June, charges that his lawyer had argued were the result of police harassment. title: Crown Hts. Youth Acquitted in Attack on Officer

body: One day last week, Max and Fay Rosenbaum were driven past the corner of President Street and Brooklyn Avenue in Crown Heights where their son was fatally stabbed four and half years ago. "They just sat there in silence," recalled Norman Rosenbaum, 38, their other son and only remaining child, who drove them by the spot. The Rosenbaums were visiting
title: A Journey From Melbourne Is a Pilgrimage for Justice

body: At twilight, when the rest of the children in the neighborhood are more likely watching television than crunching numbers, a dozen girls at the Mahalia Jackson School in Crown Heights pore over lessons in calculating means and medians. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CENTRAL BROOKLYN;Divide and Conquer: Inner-City Children Getting Into Math

body: Reversing his earlier decision, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that Lemrick Nelson Jr., the man charged with violating the civil rights of a Hasidic scholar killed during the Crown Heights violence in 1991, is to be tried as an adult rather than a juvenile. The main consequence of the decision is the sentence Mr. Nelson could face. If convicted as
title: Suspect in '91 Crown Heights Death Faces Trial as an Adult

body: They could be brothers, almost. Both are powerful Orthodox Jewish politicians from the same part of Brooklyn. title: The Gladiators of Borough Park;Rivals Compete for Power in an Orthodox Arena

title: Giuliani Wades Into the Aftermath of Jerusalem's Bombings

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CENTRAL BROOKLYN;One Election Where Votes May Not Help

title: Express Track for Jobs;Transit Tech Updates Vocational High With Courses on Modern Trains

body: MIDWOOD Haitian Voodoo Beat, Traditional and Modern The music of Haitian voodoo, in the traditional style and blended with contemporary jazz, will be performed at Brooklyn College Saturday night by artists who are part of the borough's Haitian population. The show will open with La Troupe Makandal, who began performing voodoo ceremonies in
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: The immigrant mothers sat along the edges of Brooklyn playgrounds and talked about two methods of discipline: the American way, and the way they brought with them from their homelands. American parents, they say, give a young child a timeout or ground an older one, then may even feel guilty about it. The immigrant parents believe sterner is better,
title: A Cultural Reluctance To Spare the Rod;Newcomers Say Americans Spoil Children

body: Two men taking a truck for a test drive yesterday with a salesman in Queens threw the salesman out and, chased by the police, sped into Brooklyn, where they struck and critically injured a 17-year-old girl. The victim, Rachel Teitelbaum, was walking on a sidewalk with three other girls after classes at a Talmudic seminary when the truck, a shiny
title: Carjackers Fleeing Police Strike Pedestrian

body: IN New York, where private-school tuition approaches that of Harvard University and where having a good French meal may require cashing out the money market account, it may come as a surprise that there are actually some places where you can exercise each day for less than the price of a caffe latte. title: Stretching Muscles, Not Wallets: Where to Work Out for Less

body: If anything, the Very Rev. James Parks Morton is a showman. He once exhibited a sculpture of a female Jesus, complete with bare breasts, as a statement against sexism. title: Ending Lively Era, A Dean Is Leaving St. John the Divine;The Innovator's Work Is Done, Even if the Cathedral Is Not

title: To Some, Messiah Is the Message;Media Campaign for Late Rabbi Divides Lubavitch Movement

title: Judge Orders Curfew For Stabbing Suspect

title: Inside 'City Hall'

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Lemrick Nelson, the Brooklyn man awaiting trial on Federal civil rights charges stemming from the killing of Yankel Rosenbaum during the 1991 Crown Heights disturbances, was arrested on Thursday night and charged with criminal possession of a weapon, a concealed box cutter, the police said. The police said Mr. Nelson, 20, was arrested at 9:36 P.M.
title: Crown Heights Defendant Arrested Again

body: Louis Valentino was a son of Brooklyn. He jogged the streets of Red Hook, loved sandwiches with eggplant and peppers, and worked as a lifeguard at Coney Island. But on Monday, the firefighter was killed in his home borough when the roof of an auto body shop came crashing down as he searched for people inside. He was the third firefighter to die on
title: With Firefighter's Death, Brooklyn Loses a Son

body: All these years later, the firefighters can still recall it with vivid clarity, that moment in training class when the instructor told them to survey their 150 peers and come to terms with the possibility that at least two of them would not make it out of this job alive. So come to terms with it they did, steeling their nerves and cultivating
title: Firefighters Say Risks of Job Don't Diminish Their Ardor

body: For the third time in less than six weeks, a New York City firefighter died while on duty yesterday, when the roof of an auto body shop in Brooklyn collapsed on him as he searched for people inside the building. Fire officials said the flames were so hot that they bent the metal beams supporting the roof of the one-story brick building in the
title: Roof Collapse Kills a Firefighter, 3d to Die in New York in 6 Weeks

body: The four-five signal sounded yesterday afternoon at Rescue Company 2 on Bergen Street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. In the old days it was done with bells, five peals repeated four times. Yesterday it came over the teleprinter, but the meaning was the same: One of their men, Louis Valentino, had died in action. Capt. Jay Fischler got the telephone
title: A 'Fireman's Fireman'

body: GIVEN that mainstream talk radio includes few minority hosts, local black stations like WLIB-AM and WWRL-AM have become an important sounding board for blacks. And while their listenership is comparatively limited, their impact has been considerable. It was WWRL that broadcast the rally where the Rev. Al Sharpton made the "white interloper" comment
title: The Buzz on Black Radio

body: IT is getting on toward 11 P.M. on a Wednesday, and most people are heading home from a night on the town, settling down to watch the news or dropping off to sleep. But in a soundproof studio on the 17th floor of 2 Penn Plaza, the talk radio host Jay Diamond is just warming up -- sending out to insomniacs and night owls the first of what promises
title: The Angriest Man in Talk Radio;In This City, Call-In Shows Crackle With Controversy. But When Is Enough Enough?

title: U.S. Has No Basis for Prosecuting Simpson on Civil Rights Case

body: The shaking in her left foot was certainly strange, but the doctors at the hospital were unable to pinpoint a cause, so they sent Mariana Whythe home. title: The Neediest Cases;For a Mother, Help at Home Eases Transition After Surgery

body: An accident that happened in Lakewood nine months ago could have torn the community apart, but a group that took shape in the aftermath now seems to be pulling it together. Lakewood, an aging resort town of 45,000 in Ocean County, has a diverse population of black, white and Orthodox Jewish residents, encompassing middle-class and blue-collar
title: IN BRIEF;A Coalition Helps Lakewood Bind Accident Wounds

author: Jessica Siegel is a freelance writer based in NewYork.
body: It is a little after 8 on a chilly morning and inside Prospect Heights High School in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, Peter Dillon's English as a second language class is starting to fill up. title: Pitching In Back Home

Carlebach went to great lengths to make sure that the facade of the $5 million Chabad House on the Rutgers campus in New Brunswick, N.J., will look like that of Lubavitch World Headquarters in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, known familiarly as "770." (Short for 770 Eastern Parkway). To be completed by Passover, in early April, the building
title: POSTINGS: $5 Million Lubavitcher Center Nearing Completion;A Noted Brooklyn Facade Recreated at Rutgers

body: IT seems the simplest of props: footprints are painted on the floor, a baseball bat is suspended by wires, home plate is just below. On the wall behind looms a life-size photograph of Jackie Robinson. You, the visitor, put your feet in Robinson's footsteps and step up to the plate. You grasp the bat. Suddenly, the roar of the crowd materializes all
title: Brooklyn History, Inning by Inning
